metadata.h1: One Year of Data Science Blogging — Was it Worth it?
metadata.description: It’s been roughly a year since my first article was published. Here I am, writing my 115th article — but this is the first one focused on data science soft skills. So, was it all worth it? That’s…

all_paragraphs: It’s been roughly a year since my first article was published. Here I am, writing my 115th article — but this is the first one focused on data science soft skills. So, was it all worth it? That’s what this article aims to uncover, among other things.

Here’s a quick summary — yes, blogging about data science is definitely worth it. Data science is hot right now, and new tools/libraries are released daily, so you can never run out of things to write about. For a newcomer, I think the most interesting statistic is the earning potential — so let’s get that out of the way.
Here are my average earnings for the past year (blogging only):

Is that much? In the US, probably not. In my country (Croatia), that’s about 2 average monthly salaries. So yeah, making money blogging sounds much easier for us outside the United States, if we don’t factor in the difficulties of sounding fluent in a foreign language.
Here are some other stats of mine you might find interesting:

But it’s not all about the money. I know it’s easy for me to say, but blogging isn’t a sure deal most of the time. In some months my articles get 200k+ views, and on other months I struggle to get half of that. Blogging is not your average 9–5, as there’s no guarantee on how much you’ll earn.

Also, this uncertainty won’t get you out of the bed at 5 AM, so money alone isn’t that strong of a factor. Below I’ll list and explain both the good and bad sides of committing to blogging as your side hustle, and also how to get started.
Let’s talk about good things first — as those outweigh the bad things by a large margin.

Things don’t get much better than knowing you’ve helped someone with your writing — code in this case — to solve tasks in a more simple or efficient way. Receiving positive feedback is something that happens a lot when you publish good content — both through the comment section and social media.

The latter happens more often, I have to admit, at least once a week in my case. There’s always someone on LinkedIn telling me how article X helped them to solve a problem, and after writing 100+ articles that’s just what I need to keep the motivation levels up.
I’ve read in many places that blogging is an essential tool for advancing your career and I can’t agree more. There are many reasons why, let me list a few:

The latter one is very important, as it opens up new opportunities — and good opportunities — because if an employer likes your writing there’s a good chance you’ll be respected in the company from day one.

If you’ve been in data science for more than a month you know that getting a job isn’t that easy, as most positions are senior. That’s where blogging can give you the edge, even if you don’t have enough work experience.
Besides regular job offers, every here and now a proposal for a side gig arrives — which just might be something you prefer if you intend to make blogging a daily job.
For every good thing, there’s a bad thing, and blogging is not an exception. It’s up to you to decide how much these affect you, just be prepared that not everyone will like what you have to say.
Every now and then there’s someone in the comment section who feels the need to correct my grammar.

Sure, you should always spell check your writing, but as most of us are writing in a foreign language, occasional typos are inevitable. That’s perfectly fine, as long as there aren’t too many of them in a single piece.

Be prepared — there’s always a sad person somewhere with nothing else to do just waiting for the opportunity like this. I don’t know why though, as if a single misplaced letter makes your piece unreadable. I’ve learned to ignore them, and that’s the best thing you can do.

It’s not enough to state something once — the key idea should be repeated or rephrased multiple times through the article. This is not that common in simple tutorial-based data science articles, but is quite common in opinion pieces.

Well, many times I’ve been making bold assumptions in the introduction section and prooving those assumptions later on. There’s always someone who won’t read the entire piece but will jump to the comment section asking questions that were answered in the article, just a couple of paragraphs below.
Ignoring those people is a good thing to do, as sometimes there’s just too many of them to fight with. Also, repeat the key idea multiple times through the article, as I’ve already said.

If you’ve decided to give blogging a try — congratulations, you’ve made a great decision. There are many great platforms out there, but Medium is the best place to start in my opinion, for multiple reasons:

Also, writing for a large publication makes the curation process much faster (read the curation guidelines beforehand). I’ve started by reading the Write for Towards Data Science article, checking their guidelines, and submitting my post via email.
I think that writing for TDS should be the end-goal of any aspiring data science writer, as it is a well-established publication with tons of followers and monthly views.
Don’t get discouraged if they don’t accept your piece — again, check their guidelines, and make sure your article is decent. You can always re-submit.

I’ve mentioned that Medium is a great place to start, and TDS is the place to start for any aspiring data scientist, but what if you want more freedom? That was the case for me a couple of months back, as I wanted to further diversify my income streams.
I have to admit — creating YouTube videos is so time-consuming that I haven’t committed to it 100% yet, but it’s a great option to build a following and also earn a couple of bucks down the road.
For the website, I’ve chosen to build it with WordPress, as it’s the easiest option. Still, I prefer Medium’s post editor over that buggy little thing on WordPress.
And that are 3 additional streams of income, just like that. Those will take years to build properly, but time will pass either way, so why don’t make the best of it?
To summarize — yes, you should start blogging about tech and data science as soon as possible. Here are the things you should remember:

And that’s about it. It’s not as easy as it might look, but it’s not that hard either. Also, there are so many topics to write about, at least in data science, so you shouldn’t run out of ideas any time soon.
